unnormalised: ## Ditch the Cassettes, Embrace the Stream: Music's New Avatar
normalised: ## Ditch the Cassettes, Embrace the Stream: Music's New Avatar

unnormalised: Hey guys, remember the days of painstakingly recording songs off the radio onto cassettes? Or saving up all your pocket money to buy that *one* Gulshan Kumar album? Those days feel like a distant dream, especially when you've got practically every song ever made sitting right in your pocket. Welcome to the world of music streaming!
normalised: Hey guys, remember the days of painstakingly recording songs off the radio onto cassettes? Or saving up all your pocket money to buy that *one* Gulshan Kumar album? Those days feel like a distant dream, especially when you've got practically every song ever made sitting right in your pocket. Welcome to the world of music streaming!

unnormalised: Honestly, I can't even imagine life without my daily dose of Arijit Singh while stuck in Bangalore traffic. It's a lifesaver, right? Whether you're team Spotify, Gaana, JioSaavn, or YouTube Music, the point is the same: millions of songs, personalized playlists, and the ability to discover new artists with a single tap.
normalised: Honestly, I can't even imagine life without my daily dose of Arijit Singh while stuck in Bangalore traffic. It's a lifesaver, right? Whether you're team Spotify, Gaana, J-i-o-S-a-a-v-n, or YouTube Music, the point is the same: millions of songs, personalized playlists, and the ability to discover new artists with a single tap.

unnormalised: I remember back in college at IIT Delhi, we'd spend hours huddled around someone's laptop, carefully curating playlists using LimeWire (talk about ancient history!). Now, my phone practically knows my musical tastes better than my own mother does! It throws recommendations at me based on what I've been listening to, introducing me to indie artists I'd never have found otherwise. It even knows I have a soft spot for 90s Bollywood hits like "Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge" soundtrack!
normalised: I remember back in college at I-I-T Delhi, we'd spend hours huddled around someone's laptop, carefully curating playlists using LimeWire (talk about ancient history!). Now, my phone practically knows my musical tastes better than my own mother does! It throws recommendations at me based on what I've been listening to, introducing me to indie artists I'd never have found otherwise. It even knows I have a soft spot for nineties Bollywood hits like "Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge" soundtrack!

unnormalised: But it's not just about convenience. Music streaming has also democratized the music industry. Aspiring musicians from small towns can now upload their tracks and potentially reach millions of listeners without needing a big record label backing them. That’s pretty powerful, wouldn't you say?
normalised: But it's not just about convenience. Music streaming has also democratized the music industry. Aspiring musicians from small towns can now upload their tracks and potentially reach millions of listeners without needing a big record label backing them. That’s pretty powerful, wouldn't you say?

unnormalised: Of course, there are debates about artist compensation and the fairness of royalty rates. But the bottom line is that music streaming is here to stay. It's changed the way we consume music, discover new artists, and even connect with each other.
normalised: Of course, there are debates about artist compensation and the fairness of royalty rates. But the bottom line is that music streaming is here to stay. It's changed the way we consume music, discover new artists, and even connect with each other.

unnormalised: So next time you're feeling bored on a long train journey from Mumbai to Delhi, or just need some background music for your chai time, fire up your favorite streaming app and let the music flow. After all, *picture toh abhi baaki hai, mere dost*, and so is the soundtrack to our lives. What's currently playing on your playlist? Let me know in the comments!
